part.name: Magnetometer
part.description: This instrument measures the magnetic field around the asteroid to search for evidence of an ancient magnetic field.

part.name: Solar Panel
part.description: This object absorbs the sun's rays as a source of energy for generating electricity and heating. The solar arrays power everything on board, including the science instruments.

part.name: Hall-effect Thruster
part.description: These thrusters use a electromagentic fields to expel charged atoms, or ions, of inert xenon gas that in turn create thrust.

part.name: Propellant
part.description: The Psyche spacecraft uses a propellant called xenon (a neutral gas used in car headlights and plasma TVs).

part.name: Multispectral Imager
part.description: A pair of identical cameras equipped with filters and telescopic lenses to photograph the surface of the asteroid in different wavelengths of light.

part.name: Gamma-Ray and Neutron Spectrometer
part.description: This instrument helps determine the chemical elements that make up the asteroid's surface material.

part.name: Gravity Science Experiment
part.description: This experiment uses the X-band radio telecommunications system to measure Psyche's gravity field to high precision.

part.name: DSOC
part.description: The Deep Space Optical Communication technology demonstration uses a near-infrared laser to transmit and receive high-bandwidth data.

part.name: Multilayer Insulation
part.description: This thermal material reduces heat loss by thermal radiation.

part.name: Battery
part.description: A place to store the energy collected by your solar panels.

part.name: Repair Kit
part.description: This kit repairs the damage from one collision.

part.name: Meteoroid Detector
part.description: This sensor detects meteoroids before potential collision.
